Abstract: The microcirculation plays a pivotal role in the regulation of blood flow and tissue perfusion, with its function intricately controlled by the dynamic interplay between endothelial cells, smooth muscle cells, and red blood cells. Central to this regulation is the redox switch, a mechanism that modulates vascular tone through the balance of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and nitric oxide (NO). This study delves into the molecular underpinnings of the redox switch, focusing on its impact on calcium signaling pathways within the microcirculation. By employing a multidisciplinary approach that combines biochemical assays, live-cell imaging, and computational modeling, we elucidate how alterations in redox state influence calcium dynamics in endothelial and smooth muscle cells, thereby affecting vascular reactivity. Our findings highlight the critical role of the redox switch in maintaining vascular homeostasis and its potential as a therapeutic target in diseases characterized by microcirculatory dysfunction.
